race.name: Rooted Vermont
race.tagline: Where New England gravel meets Green Mountain grit.

climate.description: Late July/August brings warm, humid conditions with potential for summer storms

terrain.primary: Classic Vermont gravel and Class 4 roads with steep pitches
terrain.surface: Varied—packed gravel to loose rocks to Class 4 'adventure' roads

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Ted King brand, premier New England gravel showcase with Class 4 roads. Overall +6 for event quality and Vermont character.

biased_opinion.summary: Rooted Vermont is what New England gravel should be—steep, beautiful, and authentically difficult. The terrain rewards complete cyclists who can climb, descend, and handle adventure roads. It's become the marquee East Coast gravel event.
strengths: Authenticity: This is real Vermont, not a manufactured course.
The terrain: Steep pitches create drama that steady climbs don't.
The destination: Kingdom Trails region is cycling paradise.
weaknesses: Accessibility: East Burke is remote even by Vermont standards.
The pitches: If you can't climb steep, this course will humble you.
Weather: Summer humidity and potential mud add variables.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want to experience New England gravel at its finest, Rooted Vermont delivers. Steep, beautiful, and genuinely challenging.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: The 'average grade' stats hide the reality. Vermont climbs in steep bursts—15-20% pitches that hurt worse than sustained 8% grades. Train for power, not just endurance.
consequences: East Burke requires intentional travel. Burlington airport is 1.5+ hours away.
Lodging is limited. Book 6+ months early or consider camping.
The pitches require specific training. VO2max work matters here.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This isn't a course you diesel through. The steep grades demand punch. Train for short, hard efforts or suffer the consequences.

final_verdict.one_liner: The New England gravel showcase—steep pitches, covered bridges, and Green Mountain beauty.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want East Coast gravel at its finest. Yes if you can handle steep grades. Not if you're strictly a tempo/steady-state rider.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want Vermont without the intensity: Vermont Overland. If you want East Coast gravel elsewhere: Rasputitsa, Gravel Worlds.

logistics.lodging_strategy: East Burke has very limited lodging. Book immediately. Consider Lyndonville, St. Johnsbury, or camping.
logistics.food: Small-town dining. East Burke has basics. Pack provisions.
logistics.parking: Start area parking available but limited. Arrive early.

history.origin_story: Created by ex-WorldTour pro Ted King and Laura King to 'cultivate a welcoming and celebratory gravel community' with a 'physically challenging and Vermont-centric race experience.' Based in Richmond, VT (not East Burke), the race showcases central Vermont's legendary gravel roads with Class IV sectors and steep punchy climbs.
notable_moments: Part of Life Time Grand Prix series
history.reputation: New England gravel at its finest. Where steep pitches and covered bridges define the experience.

course_description.character: Quintessential Vermont—steep pitches, beautiful forests, Class 4 adventure. Nothing is flat.

suffering_zones.label: First Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: The pitches start adding up. Vermont doesn't do gradual.

suffering_zones.label: Deep Woods
suffering_zones.desc: Class 4 terrain. True Vermont gravel experience.

suffering_zones.label: Final Pitches
suffering_zones.desc: Tired legs meet steep grades. Vermont isn't done yet.

course_description.signature_challenge: The pitch grades. Vermont climbs aren't long—they're steep. 15-20% pitches shred legs that expected steady grades.
